comments.commentBody: A solid Friday puzzle.  With seven 15-letter answers I feel compelled to keep any minor quibbles regarding crossword-ese to myself.  (:  I did have to guess the cross of 14D and 24A, but LISA seemed like the most probable name for an actress and Google agreed.

My experience echoed those already noted: the top half went very quickly, the bottom half took most of the time. It was a nice variety of clues and answers. Nothing too CUTESY. And, as an 8D, I found it a particularly apposite FIT. It must have taken some extraordinary juggling to get so many good words into such a full grid.

Ah, I get it now - so "Roses and Thorns" is a game they play at the White House. I guess it's an all-year round version of the dreidl game or afikomen, but one you can play with minimal props. At least Barbara Walters didn't say "Mr. President, be rosy with us."

http://blogs.abcnews.com...

"At dinner, they play a game called "Roses and Thorns." Everyone takes a turn describing a good thing that happened that day (rose) and a low moment or tough problem they had to deal with (thorn).
When the President finished his turn after a particularly challenging day at the White House (we didn't learn which one), Malia told her Dad: "You have a really thorny job."
Smart girl!
--George Stephanopoulos"
Good riddance !  I guess she got tired of entertaining  herself and educating the audience.

Bob Roistacher, why do you refer to Rudolph Leopold's "theft" of the painting? He may not have been the saint portrayed in comment #8 (and maybe he was), but he paid the Belvedere for Wally in 1954 (by trading a picture he had previously purchased). He didn't steal it.

FishGradSlave's got it right.  It seems disingenuous of the author to claim that the pyramid is inverted here.  What she suggests would violate the inviolable Laws of Thermodynamics.  Clearly, the boundaries of the ecosystem, the nature of C-imports and -exports to/from the system, and/or the trophic roles of included organisms are not yet well-defined.

From the point of view of the wee fishies, the pyramid is inverted when huge numbers of large adult salmon swim up river, too.  A locale can be attractive to large predators for reasons other than their personal dining experience.
Wow, what's up with #1 and #2? A bit too much of something there.

Maurie Beck - I am not sure how she would address an observation she admits is still a mystery. Especially since this is a blog entry and not a dissertation. Besides, the responses from readers due an excellent job at carrying the discussion further.

Big fleas have little fleas upon their backs to bite them.
little fleas have lesser fleas, and so, ad infinitum.

perhaps you are just WRONG at the % of predator biomass. We all know that Global warmists are not wrong, nor are the Gulf Oil spill predictions of permanent devastation. #2
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Perhaps they are wrong, but to compare them to scientists who have compiled mountains of evidence that global climate change is real is just rank political hackery. As to the damage caused by the Gulf oil spill, we just don't know yet, though evidence from past spills shows that damage can remain for quite some time, so to cite anything as a given right now, even in a backhanded way such as your comment, is just foolishness.
To be continued?  I hope we will hear more from Ms. Sterling on this locale and these issues!

As one who has no formal background in marine biology but a career as a scientist, I am a little surprised by the previous thread entry's final comment.  This article is clearly written for general science consumption, as a blog rather than the essay.  At least that's what the side bar "About Scientists at Work" seems to indicate.  The article is not submitted as a polished research gem, but rather to give us lay-folk a flavor of the place, the questions, and research-in-progress, and it seems to work to that effect.
Commenters 5 & 6 have a good theory.  I can weigh more that the food in my pantry.  A long distance hiker can weigh more than the food in his backpack.  It all depends on the rate of replenishment.

First of all the fact that it can support them does not mean it will forever.
And appearently because it is not a closed system we will never know unless of course someone restore a lagoon system.

Wonderful blog Eleanor, thank you so much for spreading the word about the great work you and other PARC folks are doing at the refuge!

The data you're gathering contributes to the basic knowledge of the refuge and the sea, and helps Palmyra's FWS and TNC managers better understand what actions we might take to sustain healthy populations and habitats into the future.

Mahalo!

The answer –

In a word – Pelagic. Many of the predators - such as the pictured Blue Shark – are pelagic species that feed on squid - and the lesser predators that accompany them - on the open ocean which surrounds the atoll.

I suspect that the title of this article was intended to stimulate reader interest and response. Good job! The more interest in our oceans the better.
Neat article! I'll be digging through the literature following your group as explore that unique ecosystem. Needless to say, I am intensely jealous of your career. Some people get all the luck!
Good job!  Good luck.  Thank you for your journal--I quite enjoyed it and learning about what you do.

Now that, my friends, is a crossword puzzle. Chock-full of wide-ranging erudition somehow crammed into a 15x15 grid. Even the inclusion of some old standards were tolerable with fine cluing like the clever femme mariee combo for SRAS and UNE. Glaciated ARETES are majestic, not filling.. Lotsa newbies to me, but the crosses drew out the "gotta be " answers. What were the Greek "Kyrie Eleisons" doing in my old Latin masses anyway? I dunno. Gotta ask my Mass. brother-in-law why he's been passing off those HARD CLAMS as quahogs. Fine Friday fare.
WonDERful!
And off to bed with the wistful St. Vincent Millay sonnet haunting my dreams...

It's not exactly hard to shot a rifle. But it is kind of fun. Everyone ought to take a crack at it once in their lives.
Aimlow Joe was here
http://www.aimlow.com
Terrifying.

Lets see...teaching participants to kill a man at 500 yards after lectures on how the government is enslaving us. The best reason I can think of for registering guns, knowing who has them and where they live so, when they decide to rise up, we can hunt them down like the terrorists they're training to be.

Wouldn't it be fair to say that the Revolutionary War was won when France decided to stick it to England by assisting the Colonies?

The author perfectly sums up this nonsense by pointing out that it is based upon pure fantasy. No one wants to be told what to do, or be ordered around, but it seems that this is the one country where, no matter how good things are, no matter to the extent that the U.S. is the number one country in the First World, people still insist that everything is going to hell in a handbasket.

I guess the only alternatives are 2nd and 3rd world countries, countries so small that ridiculous idealogies have a tougher time taking hold, and, of course, large swaths of Europe, where the concept of solving problems through armed conflict -- well, let's just say they finally figured out that it was not a good way to go, after it only cost 50 million lives or whatever last century.

Don't forget, fellow Tar Heels,before you head off to play soldier, you'll need to pick up your Social Security check delivered by the USPS, and to pick up your prescriptions written by your Medicare-paid doctor.

If you're house burns down while you're gone, don't worry, the government will send firefighters over to put their lives on the line (providing you live in the city).

But go ahead. These days, the Tea Party and GOP would tell you: It's Patriotic to be UnPatriotic.
